SENT.plain: OBJECTIVES: Few case-control studies of first-ever transient global amnesia (TGA), transient ischemic attack (TIA) and normal controls have been performed to date
We aimed to assess the prevalence of cerebrovascular risk factors in a well defined population of TGA patients
MATERIAL AND METHODS: We undertook a retrospective and prospective community-based case-control study of 170 first-ever TGA, 170 first-ever TIA and 170 normal controls
RESULTS: Age-matched analysis revealed that TGA cases had a significantly lower prevalence of atrial fibrillation and diabetes mellitus than TIA controls
The prevalence of cigarette smoking and diabetes mellitus was significantly higher in normal controls than in TGA cases

CONCLUSION: Our community-based case-control study showed that atrial fibrillation and diabetes mellitus, two important risk factors for cerebrovascular disease, were significantly more common in the TIA group than in the TGA one
These results make the thromboembolic pathogenesis of TGA unlikely
